explanation: The report is correct. There are two concrete ways the code can violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17: 1) If String1 (or String2) is NULL while the corresponding String1Max > 0, the code sets EndPtr1 = NULL and then FormatLen1 = String1Max. Later the function executes: if (FormatLen1 > 0) { EndPtr1 = memchr(String1, '\n', FormatLen1); memcpy(ScrubbedString1, String1, FormatLen1); } — both memchr(NULL, ..., n) and memcpy(..., NULL, n) with n>0 are undefined and result in out-of-bounds accesses. 2) Even when pointers are non-NULL, the code calls memchr(String, 0, StringMax) (and later memchr/memcpy/memcmp with lengths derived from StringMax). If the caller-provided StringMax exceeds the actual object size, these calls can read past the object bounds. MISRA 21.17 requires that use of <string.h> functions must not result in accesses beyond the referenced objects; the function does not guard against the NULL-plus-positive-size case nor against caller-supplied sizes larger than the actual buffer, so the reported violation is valid.
